newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft's Gates sees tough challenge.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft's Gates sees tough challenge.

text.p: Microsoft Corp Chairman Bill Gates said Tuesday that an array of companies supporting the network computer movement posed the stiffest challenge the software giant has seen in years.

"We have a number of competitors that are working in concert together there that pose a major challenge to us -- perhaps the largest challenge that's faced us in a long, long time," Gates said at the company's annual meeting of shareholders.

Microsoft rivals led by Sun Microsystems Inc, International Business Machines Corp, Oracle Corp and Netscape Communications Corp all back a move to new network-based computers. The so-called NC would not need Microsoft's Windows operating system and would keep most software on a central server.
Gates said Microsoft is fighting the trend by integrating Internet capabilities with all its products and working to simplify the operation and management of personal computers.

Microsoft and its ally Intel Corp last month announced thay plan a computer reference platform called the "NetPC," a response to the network computer movement intended to cut the costs of business computing.

Gates said a software component of the simplification effort called "zero-administration Windows" that would maintain user information on a server would be included in Windows NT version 5.0 due out by the end of 1997.
Gates also said Microsoft's share of the Internet browser market had risen to 15 to 20 percent, with Netscape's Navigator product still dominant.
"We feel very very good about what we've done in the past year, but we still have quite a bit of work to do," Gates said.
